conclusion: Equilateral triangle loop with side length a moves to the right at constant speed v in a magnetic field with strength B perpendicular to the loop's plane.
Side CD remains perpendicular to boundary line MN; find maximum EMF from when point D reaches boundary until point C enters field.
Induced EMF is given by Faraday's law: E = -dPhi_B/dt, where Phi_B is the magnetic flux through the loop.
Coordinate system established: Line MN is vertical (y-axis), triangle moves along x-axis, side CD is parallel to y-axis.
Height of equilateral triangle is h = a*sin(60°) = a*sqrt(3)/2; total area is A_total = sqrt(3)/4*a^2.
At time t, triangle has moved distance x(t) = vt to the right from its initial position.
Area inside the field forms a trapezoid or triangle; calculate area as a function of time.
Area inside field at time t is A(t) = 1/2*(vt)^2*cot(60°) = 1/2*(vt)^2*1/sqrt(3).
Induced EMF is E = -dPhi_B/dt = -Bv^2t/sqrt(3); magnitude increases linearly with time.
Maximum EMF at t = a/v is E_max = Bva/sqrt(3).
Point C enters field when triangle has moved distance a*sin(60°) = a*sqrt(3)/2.
Area inside field at time t is A(t) = a*sqrt(3)*vt/2 - (vt)^2/2sqrt(3).
Maximum EMF at t = 0 is |E_max| = Ba*sqrt(3)*v/2.
Final answer: Maximum induced electromotive force is |E_max| = Ba*sqrt(3)*v/2.
